conclusion: Treat the lamp as a point source situated a vertical distance H above the table.
Each object has a highest point h above the table (apple ≈ spherical, the cloth ≈ a little vertical sheet, the glass ≈ a short cylinder, the drumstick ≈ a tilted solid).
The outline (silhouette) of an object is projected on to the table by straight rays that run from every silhouette point through the lamp to the table top.
The size factor of that projection in any horizontal direction is k = H / (H – h).
The horizontal displacement of the shadow’s centre from the point right under the object’s centre is also proportional to k.
When the lamp is raised to a greater height H′ (H′ > H), the new factor k′ = H′ / (H′ – h) < k.
Every linear dimension and every horizontal shift of the shadow becomes smaller by the ratio k′/k.
Position: the whole shadow slides along the straight line that joins its present location with the point right under the object; it moves toward that foot-point.
Size: every length in the shadow is multiplied by the factor k′/k (< 1), hence the shadow is uniformly reduced (keeping its shape, only scaled).
Darkness/blur: with the lamp farther away the umbra becomes a little sharper and lighter, but that is a secondary photographic effect.
The apple casts a circular shadow ring labeled as A.
The circular shadow ring shrinks and its centre slides inward until it lies almost directly under the apple.
Result: a small dark disc almost coincident with the apple’s contact area.
The white cloth casts a roughly rectangular shadow labeled as B.
The roughly rectangular outline scales down in both width and height.
Being a vertical sheet, its present shadow is already fairly close to the object; the upward movement makes it contract further and move a few centimetres toward the cloth stalk.
The waviness of the cloth does not change the conclusion; waves simply give a slightly jagged contour that scales down in the same way.
The glass beaker casts a faint caustic/umbra shadow labeled as C.
The faint patch will pull inwards toward the beaker’s base and its diameter will decrease by the same factor k′/k.
